We also have to remember… that these are just bones. If we looked at a skeleton of an elephant (having never seen one living EVER) we would have to pretty much guess what they looked like. Their trunks are a distinguishing feature of the elephant. The trunk isn’t there in their skeleton. Furthermore, There are many tissues of the animal that break down and don’t fossilize. That could very well play a part in how they look. So dinosaurs could look VERY different from what we have been taught they look like.

I love the elegance of this explanation for the size gap among carnivorous dinosaurs. But might we be overthinking this? Near the beginning of the video, you comment on the relative paucity of dinosaur species, at least as compared with the far larger number we have today.

But isn’t it the case that fossilization is exceedingly rare? And that it’s highly likely that the fossil remains of innumerable dinosaur species have yet to be discovered, or may not be represented in the fossil record at all? So, while the idea that “middle weight” carnivorous dinosaurs were not able to compete with young adult sized members of large carnivorous theropods, perhaps this is merely an illusion created by having a non representative sample of carnivores…in other words, the gap may be a sample error assumption. It’s also possible, though less likely, that some unknown factor or factors favored the fossilization of lighter-weight, as well as very heavy, carnivores, but not those in between. This is only a suggestion as to what such factors could resemble, not a serious stab at it. But…maybe scavengers were able to find mid-sized carnivores and scatter their remains or otherwise prevent their preservation. But small carnivores’ cadavers escaped their notice, while larger remains continued to instinctually intimidate scavengers even after death. I realize such a notion sets aside herbivores, but that’s why it’s merely a suggestion of what such factors might look like, not a serious hypothesis!

So…these are only guesses. But my radar went off at the suggestion that there were a far lower number of species of dinosaur…an assertion that prima facia sounds highly suspect.

Whatever the case may be, another excellent video! I love you guys (and would if I had the chance!)

First I wouldn't call this quandary a paradox, as a paradox is a self contradictory scenario (such as a time traveler killing off itself at a previous time). The question is this: why is there a bias in the fossil record toward very large predator dinosaurs, and small predator dinosaurs? Once the proper question is asked, the potentially right answers became more obvious: either there was a selection pressure towards the ends of the size spectrum, or there was a selection pressure towards preserving of the ends of the size spectrum. It is of course naive to assume that the fossil record is complete; that it represents all the dinosaur species that lived.

How to disprove Evolution without doing any research:

Things you need or you'll die(slowly and painfully or instantaneously)

Eyes, mouth, taste buds, digestive system, bones, skin, muscles, waste excretion(poop), waste collection systems(Liver, kidney etc.), brain, and last but not least, food.

Eye and taste buds:
These called sensory nodes on a single cellular organism. Do I need to explain why you need these things or you'll die

Your taste buds have saved your life multiple times. When was the last time you bit into a rancid piece of food and spit it out? What would have happened if you ate the whole meal? Mouth:
An orifice specifically designed to intake nutrients.

Digestive system:
Cellular metabolism.(this alone is hyper complex and involves multiple subsystems)

Bones:
Structural elements vital to the moment to moment operations of the cell.

Skin:
Cellular membrane. Even water would kill a cell without its protective layer.

Muscles:
If an organism cannot move effectively it cannot gather food. Even plants orient themselves to gather sunlight.

Waste excretion(poop):
Without this any organism would either build up waste and explode or die from internal build up of toxicity.

Waste collection systems:(Liver, kidney etc.)

Brain:
Without basic instinctual intelligence cells cannot do anything much less survive(live) in a complex environment.

Food:
All food in the animal kingdom ultimately comes from the start of the food chain, Photosynthesis or chemosynthesis.

(Just an FYI, this isn’t hate, just stating my opinion) I don’t really understand how this is such a confusing “paradox.” The video questions why medium sized theropods (specifically carnivores) weren’t as common as smaller or larger ones, but I think the answer is very obvious. Smaller creatures had a very clear advantage when it came to concealment, mobility, and how little they needed to eat/drink. Larger carnivores were able to compete with larger sauropods and other various herbivores. This allowed them to satiate their hunger easier and still remain in a position of dominance over other carnivores. From a evolutionary perspective it would completely make sense for their to be less medium sized carnivores because why compete with larger carnivores you’re likely to not win against in the first place when you can instead become more of a scavenger and feed off of scraps left by them. I’m not sure if I’m just overthinking the point of this video or not, just confused with how this is even considered to be a paradox.

Hot take: maybe we have more known species of dinosaur over 1 ton because there is more bone to fossilize. As to why this leads to a large gap in medium dinosaurs, there are  loads of dinosaurs that fit the "medium" size category.

It could probably also be due to the absolutely fierce competition and evolutionary race these creatures went through. Through the fossil record you can notice that as soon as a herbivorous dinosaur increases in size and adapts better protection, a carnivorous dinosaur will soon also adapt to be bigger and evolve better hunting appendages. Just look at the evolutionary arms race between Triceratops and Tyrannosaurus.
Most herbivorous dinosaurs were massive in order to stand a chance against the equally massive predators. The reason why there wasn't a whole lot of medium sized carnivores was probably due to the fact that smaller herbivorous dinosaurs also stuck near herds of larger herbivores, meaning even though a predator was hunting smaller prey, it would've had to tussle with bigger herbivores anyways so, why not adapt to take them down?
This is probably even more apparent by the fact that nearly every small carnivorous dinosaur species were pack hunters meaning, their ability to survive was incredibly dependent on the social structure, population and location of other members of it species. Though larger carnivorous dinosaurs also had habits of hunting in packs, they weren't absolutely dependent on it, a lone Tyrannosaurus Rex could still secure a kill all be it more dangerous to do so.
Might I also note that though there wasn't a lot of medium sized dinosaurs during the cretaceous period in North America, there were a vast diverse structure of medium sized dinosaurs in South America during the cretaceous. Dinosaurs like Carnotaurus, Abelisaurus, Bajadasaurus and Irritator, just to name a few.

It is amazing how quickly and in a short time this research result has been generalized to applies to the whole world even though it originally only concerned the ecosystem where T. Rex lived. And T. Rex lived only in North America and the rest of the world ecosystems were different. In Europe, for example, most dinosaurs were medium-sized because Europe had an archipelago during the Cretaceous. And after the middle of the Cretaceous, the great dinosaurs also seem to have disappeared from Africa even though it is a large continent. This lack of big ones made room for the medium sized and can be seen from the fossils (Early Cretaceous beasts such as Spinosaurus were large, but Late Cretaceous Abelisaurids were only the size of a dromedary).  And the biggest problem with these generalizations is that you then have to explain why, for example, no fossils of T. Rex have been found in Europe, even though it was the "king of the world who ruled this entire planet." But really, T. Rex was not the undisputed emperor of the planet as people imagine, only the regional ruler of North America.

It could also be fossilisation bias. A small animals can easily be covered quickly by sediment, and can therefore relatively easily fossilise, but they are also easily scattered or completely destroyed.
A very large animal is relatively difficult to cover completely by sediment, but they are also very difficult to completely destroy and even if they are scattered the separate pieces can still be fossilised and found.
A medium sized dinosaur on the other hand, is somewhere in between these two. They're fairly difficult to completely cover, and can still fairly easily be destroyed or scattered beyond recognition.

There’s a lot of assumptions with this video, I’m not educated in ancient animals but I do spend a lot of my time studying different dinosaurs and what the earth was like millions of years ago.

So I’d like to say there are easily TONS of medium sized dinosaurs that existed along side the small and large species.

Next thing is the environment that dinosaurs lived in. If you take lots of herbivores and give them more food then they could eat, millions of years to evolve and more oxygen content than today, you have a perfect combination of factors that would give you large herbivores, when you have lots of large herbivores the carnivores need to grow larger to eat the herbivores. So you end up with lots of big dinosaurs, simple as that. Animals In an environment fill the ecological gaps in the food chain. If there is no need for medium sized creatures in an eco system they will shrink or grow to fit their proper spot in the food chain.

Lastly I’d like to add that there were hundreds of millions of years for these creatures to adapt to their environments. I honestly don’t believe most people can grasp how long that REALLY is, if someone wants to know the answer to “how come we haven’t found a lot of medium sized animals” the simple answer is we haven’t found them all yet.

I urge anyone who wants to learn more about dinosaurs and the earth millions of years ago to please take the time to study the animals that live on earth today and how they adapt and evolve to fit the world around them.

On the diversity point it’s well worth remembering that Dinosaurs like most paleontological taxa are morphospecies, specifically skeletomorphospecies.

Today if you wanted to distinguish between leopards and lions (same genus related species) you would use life appearance (skin and hair pattern) and genetics, neither of which is available to us in pretty much any Dinosaur so we go by how distinct their skeletons look.

There is a huge possibility that many specimens referred to as the same morphospecies by us would have been readily identifiable as distinct species in life. As such comments on diversity of fossil ecosystems using such data are vast overreaches.

So quick theory, and its kinda stupid but it makes a little sense to me (though it doesn't explain the gap between small and large dinosaurs). Maybe there are significantly more species of large dinosaurs that we know today than small ones.... because the big ones are much easier to find underground?

Lets say a really tiny carnivore, like the small ones in Jurassic park, have their bones scattered around 2-3 meters from their place of death in random directions. At that point, they just look like random bones, and it would be really hard to put them together into an organism.

But for an 800 ton dinosaur, scattering their bones 2-3 meters in a random direction is insignificant to the size of the original animal. The bones are huge, even 2-3 meters of scattering after death wouldn't affect a paleontologist's ability to figure out that it's one big organism. Plus on top of that, its much easier for the wind or other animals to move around small bones before they get buried, than it is for most animals/wind to move around enormous, 2000 lb bones. The smaller ones probably just got sent all over the place, lets be real.

I feel like there were medium-sized dinosaurs that we just don't know about. This is assuming that we have the full picture, and we don't. We're still making discoveries. This is assuming, as well, that certain species are entirely extinct by a certain era when they might not have been - we can only base it on the available fossils we've found. I think the statements in this are a little misleading though - there WERE medium-sized dinosaurs which were not Tyrannosaurus, just not in a timeframe that also included the Tyrannosaurus. Suchomimus, Carnotaurus, Allosaurus, Albertosaurus, Dilophosaurus, Herrerasaurus, Austroraptor, Achillobator are all among those. There were other slightly smaller theropods too. Most some raptor species didn't fall that much shorter than the smaller of these apex carnivores, while the larger medium-sized ones would be comparable to a juvenile rex. The medium-sized dinosaurs did exist, it just depended on when.

I feel like the fossil bias wasn't talked about, it often occurs since not all animals fossilize so not only is the prehistoric record incomplete because some things didn't die in places they could fossilize but it's so rare for something to be able to fossilize well that we really only have a very basic understand of what most of the Mesozoic would look like since we are looking at it in snap shots of only a few thousand years or so not the millions and millions of years it's been around. Small animals are also much less likely to fossilize, making it very hard to find animals such as early mammals in the fossil record since they wouldn't fossilize as well as something like a Tyrannosaur.
There is some evidence that teenage Tyrannosaurs did eat something different then their adult counter parts since the teeth of Nanotyrannus have different serrations then that of an adult however teeth of smaller individuals 40% grown or less seem to have the same kind of serrations as seen on adults. Along with the already huge evince of Tyrannosaurus surviving massive injuries that should have killed them, there is a very strong case that adults may have been social and taken care of their offspring but the teenagers would be kicked out to make their own pack in a fashion similar to wolves. Of course this is very hard to prove since a family group would have to die in a way that would meen they would be fossilized together and that's incredibly rare.

The way dinosaurs are preserved is through fossilization which lends itself to the whole body being covered in mud or whatever material. Larger dinosaurs would naturally not be afraid of going anywhere so they would have no reasons to avoid the areas where these events were likely to occur. Smaller dinosaurs would be much more populous but we've found less so that would mean that they too avoided the places. With that scaling even further where medium dinosaurs were incredibly unlikely to be in the locations where they would be fossilized. I only point this out because there has to be such a huge gap in the discovered species yet we are making these broad statements as to the most likely reasons for why situations occurred. I wonder if the inverse is true: the presence of medium-sized adult theropods (say, some if the larger dromeosaurs like utahraptor) means there were no mega-theropods? Or, if the same could apply to potential pack hunters: a pack would eat a variety of different prey ranging from prey normal for their size as well as those larger than expected. Plus, packs that raise their young (like almost all the mammals mentioned) won't have as big an impact on the intermediary niches since the parents will provide food to their young and skip straight to training them to hunt the larger prey.

Actually, all things considered, this could be a really interesting tool for determining if species are missing from our knowledge, if growth stages are missing, or maybe even some stuff about behavior.

Heck, this might explain some of the vulnerability of the dinosaurs to the k-pg event. There has been evidence saying speciation was decreasing before the k-pg event. Maybe that was due to this age-based niche partitioning? Also, it would make the food webs extremely vulnerable to a chain reaction since 1 extinction would effect everything related to each of the dead animal's niches. (Trex would be a sort of super-keystone species.)
